pt: {sc}anger{/sc} {sc}ire{/sc} {sc}rage{/sc} {sc}fury{/sc} {sc}indignation{/sc} {sc}wrath{/sc} mean an intense emotional state induced by displeasure. {sc}anger{/sc}, the most general term, names the reaction but by itself does not convey cause or intensity.
{sc}ire{/sc}, more frequent in literary contexts, suggests an intense anger, often with an evident display of feeling.
{sc}rage{/sc} and {sc}fury{/sc} suggest loss of self-control from violence of emotion.
{sc}indignation{/sc} stresses righteous anger at what one considers unfair, mean, or shameful.
{sc}wrath{/sc} is likely to suggest a desire or intent to punish or get revenge.

pt.t: I feared her {it}wrath{/it} if I was discovered

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}ira{/it}; perhaps akin to Greek {it}oistros{/it} gadfly, frenzy
shortdef: intense and usually openly displayed anger
